availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p:
Harrison County Kentucky
November 4th 1863.
To His Excellency Thomas E. Bramlette,
Governor of the Commonwealth of Ky.

We the undersigned jurors would most respectfully state to his Excellency Thomas E. Bramlette Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky that we were impanneled and sworn on the 3rd day of November to try a case of the Commonwealth against James Frazier a free man of color. Indicted ^in the Harrison Circuit Court^ for unlawfully coming into the state under the 6th Section of an act Approved March 3rd 1860. The evidence was that in September ^& October^ 1862, at the time this part of the state was occupied by the rebels, that many of the citizens left the county, some going to Covington some to Cincinnati. That the Deft. went to Covington, got employment about the Hotel, & conducted himself with respect and propriety, that many of the citizens of the county were in Covington & Cincinnati from the 1st of September to the 20th of October and that they did not see him in Cincinnati once. One credible wit-
=ness testified that he saw him in Cincinnati once during that time & only once, another heard him say in conversation that he had been in Cincinnati. It was also proved that he was free under the will of A. N. Frazier probated in 1848. Under the law and facts we felt bound to find him guilty, Upon these facts we extended to him all the mercy the law would allow, and feeling that it is a case worthy of further mercy we would most respectfully recommend him to the mercy and clemency of the Executive.

R S Holmes
Jas T Smith
E G Steward
Wm Hutchens
T. V. Dills
Lewis Veatch
Thomas Edwards
A J Rennekas
Aaron H. Wheeler
John Van Deven
Elijah Kirtly
J W Steward

I, James F. Ware Clerk of the Harrison Circuit Court do certify that the foregoing is a true list of the jurors in the case of the Commonwealth of Kentucky vs James Frazier a free man of color, and that they returned a verdict of guilty and assessed his punishment at one years confinement in the penitentiary.
Novr 4 1863

James F. Ware Clerk
Harrison Circuit Court
The statement in the above petition of the facts as proved upon the trial are is substantially correct
